project.teaser: Shipping is responsible for the emission of about 1 billion tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) and about 2.5% of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions worldwide. The drastic reduction of GHG emissions from ships has been set as one of the urgent targets to achieve the EU Green deal...
project.objective: Shipping is responsible for the emission of about 1 billion tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) and about 2.5% of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions worldwide. The drastic reduction of GHG emissions from ships has been set as one of the urgent targets to achieve the EU Green deal objectives. As a result, the maritime industry, which is a hard-to-decarbonize sector, is actively seeking for alternate solutions/technology which can make it more climate friendly but at the same time does not compromise on the current performance levels. Leveraging novel concepts as well as assets from former projects and initiatives, the project FuelSOME focuses on establishing the technological feasibility of a flexible, scalable, and multi-fuel capable energy generation system based on Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC) technology specially catered for long-distance maritime shipping. This system will be able to operate on Ammonia, Methanol and Hydrogen and their mixtures for which short and long-term sustainable supply pathways will be explored. Finally, on a broader level, an in-depth and detailed investigation on the environmental, social, and economic benefits of developing such a system for the European industry, the maritime sector and the citizens will be carried out. The future roadmap of the project is that the outcomes generated will not only benefit the maritime industry but can also serve as a blueprint/launchpad for implementing the same technology in other hard to abate emission sectors and/or, thereby enabling multi-fuel energy generators to become the norm in the future. The consortium comprises 8 partners: 7 partners from 6 European Member States and 1 partner from a non-associated third country (Switzerland). The FuelSOME consortium unites the necessary multidisciplinary knowledge, expertise, skills, and resources to constitute a representative value chain of actors, which together can achieve the project’s ambitious objectives.
project.title: Multifuel SOFC system with Maritime Energy vectors
project.keywords: Ammonia, Fuel cells, Maritime Transport, Methanol, Multifuel systems, Solid Oxide Fuel Cells, SOF stacks, Transport

article.title: A multi-fuel-capable solid oxide fuel cell system for the maritime industry and beyond

result.title: A: Technology concept design for a multifuel SOFC system including initial report on specifications of suitable green fuels and qualities for SOFC
result.description: A Technology concept design for a multifuel SOFC system including initial report on specifications of suitable green fuels and qualities for SOFCThis deliverable will focus on the quality of fuels required for successful SOFC stacksystem operation The amount of impurities currently present and what cleaningrefining methods will be needed prior to use in SOFC Supply chain and fuel generation pathways will also be explored

result.title: A: Initial Scientific & Technical management handbook
result.description: Scientific & Technical management handbook(The overall scientific and technical management of the project will be documented here)

result.title: A: Report on Multi fuel supply chain modelling
result.description: Report on Multi fuel supply chain modelling(This deliverable will focus on supply chain modelling of how the different fuels will be supplied to the ship or the marine port)

result.title: Solid Oxide Stack Development at Elcogen

details.authors: Matti Noponen, Jouni Puranen, Antonio Alfano, Hanna Granö-Fabritius

result.title: Data Management Plan
result.description: DMPThe data generated from several tasks from different work packages needs to be managed in a responsible manner A detailed report how this vast amount of data will be handled will be chalked out here

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - FuelSOME (Multifuel SOFC system with Maritime Energy vectors)
result.teaser: The FuelSOME project aims to creating multifuel Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFC) systems optimized for maritime applications, particularly for oceanic vessels. It investigates the viability of utilizing hydrogen, ammonia, and methanol as multifuels, with a focus on sourcing these...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

result.title: A: Initial PEDR
result.description: The deliverable consists of the project’sinitial, PEDR identifying key stakeholder groups with engagement strategies and tactics.

result.title: B: Technology concept design for a multifuel SOFC system including final report on specifications of suitable green fuels and qualities for SOFC
result.description: B) - Technology concept design for a multifuel SOFC system including final report on specifications of suitable green fuels and qualities for SOFC(This deliverable will be the final report on what are the exact specifications of the fuels viz. ammonia, methanol and hydrogen in terms of fuel quality for use in SOFC stack/system along with defined supply chain pathways and fuel generation pathways)

result.title: A: Initial report on stack performance with simulated multifuel feed
result.description: Initial report on stack performance with simulated multifuel feed(Stack operation with multi-fuels is key to the success of the project. The stack performance with multi-fuel feed will be evaluated in the initial phase and the report will document the initial findings)

result.title: Report on TEA and LCSA methodology and overarching impact assessment framework
result.description: Report on TEA and LCSA methodology and overarching impact assessment framework(The technoeconomic Analysis and the Life Cycle Sustainability Assessment will be carried out for the whole concept)

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
